#Text=Justynian
#Text=Szczytt ( d. 1677 )
#Text=For the member of the Permanent Council , see Justynian Szczytt ( 1740 – 1824 ) .

#Text=Justynian Niemirowicz Szczytt ( also spelled Szczyt and Szczyth ; died 1677 ) was a Polish nobleman ( szlachcic ) , a chamberlain ( podkomorzy ) of Polotsk and a deputy to the sejm ( parliament ) of the Polish – Lithuanian Commonwealth .
#Text=For many years he was a servant of the magnate Sapieha family .
#Text=He was vice wojewoda ( vice governor ) of Polotsk ( probably 1666-70 ) and chamberlain ( podkomorzy ) of Polotsk from 1673 .
#Text=Szczytt was a sejm deputy in 1667 , 1668 , 1669 , 1670 and 1674 .
#Text=He was also a founder of the Franciscan cloister at Prozaroki ( Polish Prozoroki ) .
#Text=Family
#Text=Justynian Szczytt was a member of the Szczytt family , which used Jastrzębiec as its coat of arms [ 1 ] ( although according to Kasper Niesiecki , it was not Jastrzębiec , but Radwan [ 2 ] ) .
#Text=Justynian 's great-grandfather was Mikołaj Szczytt , wojski of Witebsk , who spent 15 years in captivity in Moscow . [ 1 ]
#Text=Justynian was the son of Krzysztof Szczytt , owner of Białe in Polotsk Voivodeship , and his wife Zofia Lissowski .
#Text=After the death of Krzysztof Szczytt , Zofia married Józef Skinder .

#Text=Justynian Szczytt had five siblings : three brothers — Jan ( d. between 15 October 1668 and 23 April 1672 ) , Mikołaj ( wojski of Mścisław , d. 1676 ) , and Aleksander — and two sisters — Anna and Halszka . [ 3 ] [ 4 ]
#Text=Information of Justynian Szczytt 's sons in Herbarz polski by Kasper Niesiecki
#Text=Justynian Szczytt married Anna Joanna Tukowicz ( d. 1694 ) , daughter of Bazyli Tukowicz , in 1648 .
#Text=They had six sons :
#Text=Konstanty Marcjan , b. about 1649 , d. 17 or 22 October 1712 ; podsędek ( deputy district judge ) of Polotsk , elector of Michał Korybut Wiśniowiecki , Jan III Sobieski and August II
#Text=Bronisław , d. between 2 June 1668 and 1675
#Text=Krzysztof Benedykt , d. 1720 ; castellan of Smolensk
#Text=Samuel Karol , d. 24 December 1709
#Text=Albrecht ( Olbracht , Olbrycht ) , d. 22 August 1694 ; podstoli of Smolensk
#Text=Kazimierz , b. 29 November 1664 , d. 8 September 1708 ; Jesuit . [ 5 ]
#Text=Life
#Text=Nothing is known about the date or place of Justynian Szczytt 's birth , nor his education and youth .
#Text=He was a servant of the magnat Sapieha family for many years , particularly of Paweł Jan Sapieha and his son Benedykt Paweł Sapieha .
#Text=He administered property in Czereje in their names from 1667 to 1669 . [ 5 ]
#Text=By 22 June 1666 , he had become Polotsk 's vice- voivode ( podwojewodzi , literally : under-voivode ) . [ 5 ]
#Text=In 1667 , Szczytt was elected for the first time as a member of the sejm walny ( parliament ) of the Polish – Lithuanian Commonwealth as a representative of the Połock Voivodeship .

#Text=The following year he served as a member of parliament twice : first in the extraordinary parliament ( sejm ekstraordynaryjny ) and again in the abdication sejm after King Jan Kazimierz abdicated the throne . [ 5 ]
#Text=Election of Michał Korybut Wiśniowiecki
#Text=Szczytt was member of parliament during the election sejm of 1669 , which elevated Michał Korybut Wiśniowiecki to the Polish throne .
#Text=According to family tradition , Szczytt saw that people were giving new king an ordinary-looking szabla .
#Text=He gave the king his own very ornamental sabre .
#Text=Eventually the szabla was returned to Szczytt , and it remained a family heirloom until the 1880s . [ 6 ]
#Text=Also in 1669 , Szczytt was a member of the coronation sejm .

#Text=He tried to stop the proceedings of parliament for an unknown reason on 25 October 1669 , but the following day he retracted his objection on the condition that the Połock Voivodeship be exempt from taxes for a period of six years . [ 5 ]
#Text=By 29 July 1670 , Kazimierz Jan Sapieha , Połock 's new voivode , named Szczytt the new podwojewodzi . [ 5 ]
#Text=Historians believe Sapieha did so in exchange for Szczytt 's property in Lisna . [ 5 ] Also in 1670 , Szczytt was a judge of the Lithuanian Tribunal .
#Text=In June 1670 , on behalf of the Sapieha family , he accused Mikołaj Ciechanowiecki , Marshall of the Tribunal , of several crimes , including being elected illegally .
#Text=Then Szczytt left Wilno and paralysed the Tribunal for some time .
#Text=Eventually , the Tribunal won the support the magnate Pac family and Szczytt was banished . [ 5 ]
#Text=That same year , Szczytt was a member of parliament .
#Text=Between 6 June and 10 August 1673 he became Polotsk 's podkomorzy ( chamberlain ) . [ 5 ]
#Text=As podkomorzy he was known from his judiciousness .
#Text=He became known as sprawiedliwy Szczyt ( " Justice Szczytt " ) . [ 6 ]
#Text=During election Sejm of 1674 he voted for Jan III Sobieski . [ 5 ] [ 6 ]
#Text=In 1677 Szczytt brought the Franciscan Brothers to Prozaroki , where he built them a cloister and church . [ 5 ]
#Text=Justynian Szczytt died in 1677 [ 5 ] ( although Teodor Żychliński states that Szczytt died about 1681 [ 6 ] ) .
#Text=He was buried in the Franciscan church in Prozaroki . [ 5 ]
#Text=Estate
#Text=Szczytt was an owner of the several villages .
#Text=From his father he inherited Białe .

#Text=Later he bought some more : Truchonowicz , Kozłów and Słobódki from Jerzy Atełchowski , Hubin and island on Otułow 's river from Jakub Iwanowicz Suprynowicz Bużycki and his wife Halsza in 1654 .
#Text=Szczytt was also owner of parts of some villages .
#Text=He bought part of Tabołki and Prozaroki from his brother-in-law Stefan Tukowicz ( first in 1663 , second in 1666 ) and part of Sanniki from Michał Skarżyński in 1674 .
#Text=He was also mentioned as owner of Komorowszczyzna , Ołoskowo and Pohorełe .
#Text=Justynian Szczytt had as lien the following villages : Doroszkowice ( Dorozińce ) , Babcze , Czerniewicz , Woroszki , Mamonowszczyzna , Szypiłłowszczyzma , Świerzno and Dziernowice .
#Text=Szczytt divided his property among his sons in 1675 . [ 5 ]
